title: What happened to the Cowboys' run D vs. Packers? Jerry Jones, players explain
text:
CLOSE What I'm Hearing: USA TODAY Sports' Jori Epstein spoke with members of the Cowboys following their 34-24 loss to the Packers on Sunday. USA TODAY

ARLINGTON, Texas — On Aaron Jones’ first touchdown, he pointed up to the AT&T Stadium ceiling before gathering his teammates in the end zone, arms crossed, to mug for a cameraman.

“This is my house,” he exclaimed after his second touchdown advanced the Packers’ rout of the Cowboys.

By his third, Jones was waving goodbye to Cowboys cornerback Byron Jones before he even broke into the end zone. Aaron Jones carried the ball with one hand while waving with the other, and still the defender couldn’t catch him.

So by Jones’ fourth touchdown, a one-yard punch up the middle, the Packers running back blew a kiss to the camera man. Quarterback Aaron Rodgers raised four fingers to count them off.

Aaron Jones eludes Cowboys CB Byron Jones, waves goodbye...



Packers 24. Cowboys 0.pic.twitter.com/y2DaNNZPag — Jori Epstein (@JoriEpstein) October 6, 2019

The Cowboys defense seemed unable to point even one finger at an answer.

“There’s no question we didn’t tackle well,” linebacker Sean Lee said. “All of us didn’t tackle well. That’s something we usually hang our hat on ... Just traditionally, that’s what we do, but we didn’t do it today.”

The Cowboys’ 34-24 loss reads as much closer than how the game actually unfolded for most of Sunday afternoon. With 2:10 to play in the third quarter, the Cowboys trailed 31-3 in their own house. Jones had scored four touchdowns before the Cowboys scored one. And he became the first opponent in the 59-year Cowboys franchise history to gash Dallas for four rushing touchdowns.

Since Cowboys became a team in 1960, no RB had scored 4 TDs on them, per @Boys_Vox. Until today.



Aaron Jones: 155 total yards, 4 TDs — Jori Epstein (@JoriEpstein) October 6, 2019

By the time the defense regrouped to allow just 14 yards of offense in the fourth quarter, it was too late.

“We can’t wait for a couple of explosive runs to decide that, ‘Oh, we’re going to buckle up and trust each other and play more disciplined,’” linebackers coach Ben Bloom told USA TODAY Sports. “We need to do that from the start of the game.”

They’ll look to execute that plan Sunday afternoon against the 0-4 New York Jets.

The Jets’ 66 rushing yards per game ranks third worst in the league, ahead only of the Cincinnati Bengals and Miami Dolphins. The Cowboys have allowed at least 117 rushing yards in three of their five contests so far, including both losses. Players and coaches said they will hammer further this week on basic fundamentals, setting the edge, gap fits, assignments and aggressive tackling. But players from the largely intact fifth-best run D in 2018 left this Packers loss baffled by a Green Bay team they had felt prepared to take on. The Cowboys insisted they weren’t surprised by scheme as much as they failed to execute.

“A poor performance by me,” second-year linebacker Leighton Vander Esch lamented, adding to his list of issues “bad footwork” and “bad tackling.” Defensive lineman Tyrone Crawford said simply: “We messed up and we have to fix that.”

Aaron Jones left the Cowboys defense looking for answers. (Photo: Tim Heitman, USA TODAY Sports)

With Cowboys nose tackle Antwaun Woods (knee) expected to work more into practice this week, one key cog in clogging the lane should soon return. But the front seven will need to improve its communication to reduce the rampant missed tackles they fell victim to against Green Bay. They can’t let the threat of a mobile quarterback derail their gap coverage inside.

“We know firsthand that when you've got to defense a quarterback like Rodgers, you got to contain him,” owner Jerry Jones said. “You also got to defend him. We let him out of containment quite a bit and you saw what he did to us. When you're doing all that, that opens those lanes up.”

“The story of the game were the turnovers and our inability to stop the run. … That was a little surprising to not be able to stop their run better than we did tonight.

When the Cowboys host the Eagles in two weeks, they’ll face a similarly mobile quarterback in Carson Wentz. The Eagles rank just 18th in rushing with 111.8 yards per game, but that’s 25.5 more than the Packers came to AT&T Stadium averaging. It didn’t matter. The stakes will only heighten in the NFC East matchup as an Eagles team currently riding a two-game win streak has caught the Cowboys at 3-2. Dallas now holds a lead only on account of the division-play tiebreaker. Without improved run defense, their lead will continue to fade into a remnant of a 3-0 past.

Players assured they have the tools to make those changes.

“It was all on us,” Crawford said. “We didn’t do our job and we didn’t stay in our gaps.

“We do our jobs and a lot of those things are stopped.”

description: Aaron Jones gashed the Dallas Cowboys  for four TDs before they could score one in Sunday's loss against the Green Bay Packers.
